title: Synthetic Recap
body:
BOSTON – On a night where the hardwood floor of the old Boston Garden seemed to ignite, Kevin Willis didn’t just score; he authored a masterpiece. The Phoenix Suns’ big man delivered a performance for the ages, pouring in a career-high 46 points to will his team to a stunning 112-108 victory over the Boston Celtics in 1998.

From the opening tip, Willis was unstoppable. He dominated the painted area with an array of powerful post moves and feathery touch, amassing his monumental total on efficient shooting. While the Celtics, led by the steadying presence of Rick Fox who notched a triple-double with 20 points, 13 rebounds, and 10 assists, fought valiantly on their home floor, they had no answer for the Suns’ force in the middle.

The game tightened into a classic fourth-quarter tug-of-war, with every possession magnified. But each time Boston threatened, Phoenix went back to its bedrock. Willis, a pillar of consistency all night, continued to convert, carrying the Suns’ offense on his broad shoulders. His 46 points were not just a personal best; they were a historic outburst that carved through the Celtics’ defense and silenced a legendary arena.

While teammates like Wesley Person provided crucial support with 19 points, this night belonged unequivocally to one man. Kevin Willis’s 46-point tour de force was more than enough to secure the road win, a singular, legendary effort that will forever be etched in the annals of both the franchise and the era.
